headline: Chicken Paitan Broth (Tori Paitan Dashi) Recipe
description: Chicken paitan broth is the chicken-based cousin of tonkotsu ramen broth—creamy, rich, and perfect for noodle soups.
name: Chicken Paitan Broth (Tori Paitan Dashi) Recipe
keywords: Asian, broth, chicken, chicken soup, fall, ramen, soup, winter

nutrition.servingSize: Makes a little over 1 quart (950ml) broth, enough for 3 bowls of ramen

recipeIngredient: Leftover strained chicken carcass and vegetables from chintan shoyu ramen broth (see note)
1 leek (about 10 ounces; 300g), including dark-green parts, sliced crosswise very thinly and washed well of sand
1 medium carrot (about 6 ounces; 170g), peeled and diced
One 1-inch piece ginger, peeled and thinly sliced
1/4 ounce kombu (7g; about one 7- by 2-inch piece)

recipeInstructions.text: If Using Spent Chicken Carcass and Vegetables From Chintan Ramen Broth Recipe: Place spent chicken carcass in a pressure cooker and cover with 6 1/4 cups (1.5L) water. (No matter what, be sure not to exceed the max-fill line of your cooker.) Bring to high pressure and cook for 1 hour and 20 minutes. Allow pressure to release naturally.

Using an immersion blender, blend contents of pressure cooker into a porridge-like slurry (see note). Alternatively, transfer contents of pressure cooker in batches to a high-quality countertop blender and blend. You can also use a wooden spoon or potato masher to break up and crush the chicken parts in the pot into small bits; however, you will then need to boil the mixture over high heat, stirring periodically, for 30 minutes in order to emulsify the broth.

Working in batches, pour mixture through a fine-mesh strainer directly into mixing bowl filled with spent vegetables and kombu from chintan broth. Press firmly on solids to extract as much liquid as possible. Discard strained chicken solids.

Let broth steep for 30 minutes. Strain broth through a fine-mesh strainer into a clean mixing bowl, pressing firmly on vegetables to extract as much broth as possible. Discard vegetables. Transfer broth to airtight containers and refrigerate.

If Using Fresh Chicken and Fresh Vegetables: Place chicken in a pressure cooker and cover with 6 1/4 cups (1.5L) water. (No matter what, be sure not to exceed the max-fill line of your cooker.) Bring to high pressure and cook for 2 hours. Allow pressure to release naturally.

Using an immersion blender, blend contents of pressure cooker into a porridge-like slurry (see note). Alternatively, transfer contents of pressure cooker in batches to a high-quality countertop blender and blend very briefly, just to break up larger bones. You can also use a wooden spoon or potato masher to break up and crush the chicken parts in the pot into small bits; however, you will then need to boil the mixture over high heat, stirring periodically, for 30 minutes in order to emulsify the broth.

Working in batches, strain chicken mixture through a fine-mesh strainer directly into a large heatproof mixing bowl, pressing firmly on the mixture to ensure that all the liquid has been extracted. Discard chicken solids.
Add broth to a pot and bring mixture to a boil over high heat. Turn off heat and add leek, onion, carrot, garlic, and ginger. Stir mixture once and add kombu. Let steep for 40 minutes.

Pour broth through a fine-mesh strainer into a clean, large heatproof mixing bowl, pressing on solids to extract as much liquid as possible. Discard vegetables. Transfer broth to airtight containers and refrigerate.

review.reviewBody: Late to the party, but I did the spent-carcass version of this after making the chintan shoyu ramen, and my immersion blender churned right through all the bones. I was equal parts terrified and delighted, but put it through a muslin bag because I didn't think my strainer was fine enough to catch all the bits. Haven't made the ramen part yet, but totally obsessed with this creamy, flavorful, and thrifty approach.

Do I need to include the meat in the bones? I’d like to use the meat for another recipe and just blend the bones and skin (and the meat that’s a pain to remove, like wings and back). Would it still work?

Hey Sho,

I've been on a ramen kick in 2021 and I've made this recipe three times, using fresh chook and veg. It's excellent with one issue- my yield is consistently terrible. Despite pressing the hell out of the poultry gruel, my yield is topping out at ~500-600ml- nowhere near the expected yield, which explains why I'm asking on it.

To this point, I've been combining the first cook with a second cook I make thereafter (excellent yield) just for some volume, but I'd really like to get a proper Paitan with a decent yield on the first go. Any tips or suggestions to increase the yield? Thanks! Fun recipe!

Hi,
I made this recipe from the spent carcass and I reused the vegetables. 

It developed a 3 mm (or so) fat film overnight. Is it a good idea to skim this fat and make aroma oil, like in the chintan shoyu recipe?

It's also very gelatinous, I don't mind it but is this how it's supposed to be when cooled down?

Definitely the chicken version of Tonkotsu when it comes to effort and creamy broth. Makes for an excellent base for your own tare.

Pressure cooked it for 2 hours and my old immersion blender was able to make short work of the bones. Grabbed a piece of bone and squeezed it between my fingers first to make sure it would be soft enough for the blender and sure enough, it crumbled.

Rather than discarding the meat, I ended up using the strained chicken mush for chicken salad. I noticed that it resembled canned chicken/tuna that's been drained. If you're like me and hate seeing a whole chicken go to waste, give it a shot and mix it with mayonnaise, vinegar, black pepper, and celery (and anything else you want to add). It might be more mealy than regular because there's obviously bone bits and marrow there, but I wasn't bothered by it since it was fairly hard to distinguish in salad form.

item.name: Chicken Paitan Broth (Tori Paitan Dashi) Recipe
